Graphical abstract Microwave-assisted acetalization of glycerol to solketal over transition metal promoted mordenite catalysts. The present study demonstrates a clean and green approach for the production of bio-fuel additives from renewable glycerol acetalization using microwave irradiation as heating method. Various transition metal ion (M=Fe-, Co-, Ni-, Cu- & Zn-) promoted mordenite solid acid catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method and examined for the acetalization of glycerol with acetone. Investigation of the structural and chemical properties of the catalysts was achieved using XRD, FT-IR, TGA-TPD, SEM/EDX and XPS techniques. Comparative studies using conventional heating were performed in order to study the efficiency of microwave-assisted acetalization reactions. The effect of various operating parameters on the catalytic activity studies was examined. Amongst the metal-promoted mordenite catalysts tested, Cu-Mor had the best performance due to the presence of a large amount of acidic sites and the synergetic effects of metal particles interacting with mordenite. Microwave-assisted acetalization of glycerol into Solketal was found to be an energy efficient route for glycerol valorization achieving 98% selectivity to solketal at 95% glycerol conversion during a reaction time of 15min over Cu-Mor catalyst and acetone/glycerol at a molar ratio of 3:1. Reuse of spent catalyst showed good repeatability for up to four reaction cycles with a marginal decrease in conversion. Keywords Solketal Glycerol Mordenite Acetalization Microwave irradiation 1 Introduction The utilization of non-renewable energy sources for energy and fuel production is not a sustainable approach in view of diminishing fossil fuel resources and increased emission of greenhouse gases [1]. In order to achieve a sustainable biosphere, the use of renewable resources as replacements for fossil fuels is more important and researchers have focussed their attention on the exploration of renewable energy sources for future energy needs. In this regard, Biomass was identified as an outstanding renewable source and a potential alternative to fossil fuels for production of fuels, fuel additives and fine chemicals [2,3]. Biodiesel is such commonly used renewable fuels produced by the transesterification of biomass derived plant oils or animal fats with methanol [4]. As petro diesel is currently a major requisite for nearly all kinds of transport means, Biodiesel stands as the most promising sustainable substitute to diesel fuels and its usage has already been extended to various parts of the world. It can be used in its purest form in existing diesel engines or can be easily blended with petroleum diesel. Unlike petroleum-based diesel, biodiesel has certain unique advantages as it is biodegradable, nontoxic emitting less air pollutants/greenhouse gases, relatively economical, enhanced lubricating property and combustible properties highly compatible to diesel engines [5]. Yet, biodiesel suffers from the problem of engine clogging and found to be less appropriate for its use in low temperature regions. On the other hand, the increased use of biodiesel is hindered by the large amount of glycerol obtained as a co-product in the biodiesel production which would greatly affect the cost affordability of biodiesel processes [6,7]. Therefore, finding and developing feasible methods to dispose or effectively use the excess glycerol in value adding chemical processes is vital and may possibly lessen both environmental contamination and profitable losses (Scheme 1 ). Glycerol (1,2,3-propanetriol) is a versatile bio feedstock and has been emerged as a fascinating platform molecule for the synthesis of biofuel additives and variety of chemical intermediates due to its non-toxic and multifunctional structure [8]. To this end, extensive research has been developed for up gradation of glycerol by various catalytic transformations to valuable chemicals. Several strategies including etherification [9], hydrogenolysis [10,11], dehydration [12], acetalization [13], esterification [14], oxidation [15] and steam reforming [16] have been explored. In the recent past, special interest was focussed on synthesis of acetals and ketals by the acid catalyzed acetalization of glycerol with aldehydes and ketones. These are commercially important branched oxygenated compounds finding numerous applications as disinfectants, fuel additives, flavouring agents, cosmetics, surfactants, pharmaceuticals, food and beverage industries [17]. In particular, the glycerol acetalization with acetone gives 5-membered and 6-membered cyclic isomeric compounds namely (2,2-dimethyl-[1,3] dioxane-4-yl)-methanol (also known as Solketal) and 2,2-dimethyl-[1,3] dioxane-5-ol respectively (Scheme 2 ). Solketal is a potential fuel additive and an anti-knocking agent which aids in enhancing the octane number and leads to a significant decrease in harmful emissions when blended with diesel fuel [18]. It is a chief constituent used in the preparation of gasoline, and biodiesel fuels that effectively reduces the viscosity, enhances the cold flow properties besides attaining the flash point and oxidation stability of biodiesel during extended storage [19]. In a recent report by Garcia et al. [20] it was established that the viscosity and other properties of biodiesel improved significantly by the use of fuel additives. In search of new bio-degradable, non-toxic and renewable fuel additives for biodiesel, the synthesis of solketal from bio derived glycerol and its usage finds great demand. Conventionally, the acetalization of glycerol with acetone is performed over homogenous liquid acids and Lewis acid catalysts [13]. However, the use of homogenous acid catalysts is not cost-effective and presents environmental harms in addition to tough work-up processes. Thereby, heterogeneous catalysts are well chosen in view of clear benefits over homogeneous acids for example their reusability, solvent less conditions, product selectivity and above all, quite easy separation of products from catalysts [21]. Several heterogeneous solid acid catalysts including sulphonic acid mesostructured silicas [22], supported heteropolyacids [23], promoted zirconia [24], supported metal oxides [25], zeolites [26], and promoted metal phosphates [27] have been tested in the glycerol acetalization reaction. Although proven to be efficient, their activity is still hampered by poor thermal stability, low surface area, solubility in polar solvents, reduced regeneration ability and use of hazardous solvents and high temperatures. Therefore, to achieve a sustainable and economical process of glycerol acetalization, it is indispensable to develop highly efficient, inexpensive and thermally stable catalysts. In this intellect, protonic zeolites seem to be the most promising and widely applied acid catalysts in the chemical industry. In addition to presenting the apparent benefits of heterogeneous catalysts like reusability and simple recovery, protonic zeolites exemplify eco-friendly solid acid catalysts unlike conventional liquid acids. These are aluminosilicates characterized by uniform microporous crystalline structure, shape selectivity, hydrophobicity and high thermal stability. It is ascertained that the stronger acidity of protonic zeolites is consistent with the bridging hydroxyl groups Al(OH)Si located in the cavities of zeolite [28]. H-Mordenite is one such protonic zeolite found to hold excellent structural and textural properties that are not seen in other catalytic materials. Unlike other zeolites, even though mordenite is a microporous material, it possess a special multiple pore channel system where its elliptical pores are wide enough to allow many reactions to be attained with high selectivities. Mordenite is a strong Brønsted acidic zeolite, chemically composed of Na8Al8Si40O96·24H2O with a Si/Al molar ratio ≥5 and highly stable towards chemical and thermal treatments. Mordenite is well considered for its use in chemical sensors, optics and semiconductors in addition to the adsorptive separation of liquid or gaseous mixtures. It is extensively used as a catalyst in various reactions such as reforming, hydroisomerization, dewaxing, hydrocracking and alkylation owing to its surface acidity and distinctive pore system [29,30]. The formation of water during glycerol acetalization reaction is problematic and has to be addressed in order to hinder the reverse reaction. The hydrophobic property of the zeolite assists in inhibiting the reverse reaction of acetalization by diffusion of water in to the pores of zeolite. da Silva et al. [31] reported the same phenomenon in beta zeolite catalyzed glycerol acetalization reaction with acetone at 70°C. The modification of physiochemical properties of zeolites to further improve their efficiency in reactions can be achieved by the incorporation of metal atoms into the framework or extra framework of zeolite structure. Most of the liquid phase reactions over heterogeneous catalysts were conducted by direct heating or in oil bath which is an inefficient and slow process in terms of energy transfer from source to the reactants. Microwave-assisted chemical synthesis has become increasingly popular and is proven to be more efficient than conventional heating method because of its high speed synthesis involving rapid internal heating, with a direct transfer of microwave energy from source to the molecules in the reaction. Microwave processing brings about uniform heating that can regulate the temperature and brings about considerable energy saving [32,33]. Hence, the chemical syntheses by microwave irradiation as heating method receive significant interest over traditional heating methods offering high conversion and selectivity. In an effort to develop an economic viable and a green chemical protocol, the present work focussed on solvent-free microwave-assisted synthesis of solketal from glycerol acetalization with acetone over Mordenite (Mor) and transition metal promoted mordenite (Fe-Mor, Co-Mor, Ni-Mor, Cu-Mor & Zn-Mor) catalysts. Various transition metal-promoted mordenite catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method and thoroughly investigated for its structural, chemical and acidic properties by using various techniques such as XRD, FTIR, SEM/EDX, XPS and TGA-TPD. These catalysts with varied properties were tested in glycerol acetalization via microwave irradiation method in order to screen out the most efficient catalyst. Then, an optimization study was performed for attaining maximum conversion and selectivity by different reaction parameters including reaction temperature, glycerol concentration, glycerol/acetone mole ratio and reaction time. In addition, a comparative study of solketal synthesis by conventional heating is also described. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of transition metal promoted mordenite catalysts (M-Mor) were prepared by wet impregnation method. H-Mordenite with SiO2/Al2O3 ratio 20 and a surface area of ∼540m2/g was supplied from Conteka, Netherlands. In a typical procedure, the required amounts of 1wt% metal nitrate precursors (M(NO3)2; M=Fe, Co, Ni, Cu & Zn) were dissolved in millipore water and allowed to stir for 10min to obtain uniform suspension. This was followed by the addition of finely powdered H-mordenite to the aqueous metal nitrate solution under stirring. The sample obtained after evaporation of excess water was oven dried at 110°C for 15h and finally calcined in air at 550°C for 4h. The as-prepared mordenite supported metal catalysts are herein labelled as Fe-Mor, Co-Mor, Ni-Mor, Cu-Mor and Zn-Mor. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies were performed on a Bruker D8 X-ray diffraction system and the measurements were conducted in the range of 2θ 10.0° to 90.0° using a voltage of 40kV and current of 40mA with CuKa radiation. FTIR spectra of the catalysts were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 spectrophotometer, in diffuse reflectance mode with the spectral resolution of 4cm−1. SEM/EDX studies of the catalysts were obtained by a FEI nova nano SEM operated at 30kV accelerating voltage. XPS data of M-Mor catalysts was collected using a Thermo k-Alpha XPS instrument with core levels aligned with C 1s binding energy of 284.6eV and a pressure of 1×10−9 torr. TGA-TPD experiments for mordenite catalysts were conducted using ammonia as a base molecule. Initially, the catalyst samples were pretreated in a flow of nitrogen atmosphere at 550°C at 10°C/min in order to remove adsorbed water and other volatiles completely. This is followed by the adsorption of ammonia on the catalyst samples for about 30min. The sample was then heated to 700°C at a rate of 10°C/min under the flow of nitrogen, and the ammonia desorption was continuously recorded as a function of temperature. NH3 adsorbed catalysts Thermo gravimetric data (TG) were collected using a Perkin Elmer TGA-7 from 35°C to 700°C with a heating rate of 10°C per minute under the flow of nitrogen. 2.3 Reaction procedure 2.3.1 Microwave-assisted reaction The glycerol acetalization reaction was carried out in CEM Discover-S (NP1009) high pressure and high temperature microwave reactor equipped with magnetic stirring and temperature cooling system. The mixture of glycerol (1mmol), acetone (3mmol) and 40mg of the catalyst were taken in a reactor vessel fitted with a PTFE-lined cap and is irradiated under high power (100–600W) to reach reaction temperature of 100°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The reactor vessel was run under continuous stirring for 15min in the microwave reactor. The reactor vessel was then allowed to cooling and the reaction products were extracted and filtered by separating the used catalyst by centrifugation. The products were analyzed on HP5890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The products were analyzed and confirmed by GC-MS. 2.3.2 Room temperature reaction A mixture of glycerol (1mmol) and acetone (3mmol) was subjected to vigorous stirring in a RB flask at room temperature in the absence of any solvent. After 5min, the catalyst (40mg) was added and the reaction time started. The products were analyzed and confirmed by GC-MS and quantitative analysis was analyzed on a HP5890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The conversion of glycerol and selectivity of solketal were calculated based on the following equations: Glycerol Conversion ( % ) = moles of glycerol ( ini ) − moles of glycerol ( Final ) moles of glycerol ( in ) × 100 Solketal Selectivity ( % ) = moles of solketal formed moles of glycerol converted × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction studies XRD patterns of pure mordenite and transition metal promoted mordenite catalysts (Fe-Mor, Co-Mor, Ni-Mor, Cu-Mor and Zn-Mor) revealed the presence of characteristic peaks of mordenite zeolite at 2θ =9.76°, 13.52°, 19.70°, 22.42°, 25.73°, 26.44°, and 27.64° which is similar to the respective mordenite diffraction peaks found in the literature [34,35]. As shown in Fig. 1 , all of the samples presented similar crystallinity and no significant differences were observed in the mordenite structure after metal impregnation. Consequently the absence of metal/metal oxide peaks in the diffraction patterns suggests that these metal ions were highly dispersed on the mordenite surface. This confirms that all of the transition metal ions promoted mordenite materials did not alter the structure of the zeolite and retain the high crystallinity of mordenite. 3.1.2 Fourier transform-infrared spectra The structure of mordenite and the presence of surface hydroxyl groups has been studied by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy in the range of 4000–500cm−1 and the spectral results of pure mordenite and metal promoted mordenite catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . All the samples reveal the typical vibrational bands of mordenite which agree with the previous reports [36]. The FTIR spectra of pure mordenite exhibit two stretching vibrational peaks at 3744cm−1 and 3605cm−1 associated with the terminal silanol groups and the bridging Si-OH-Al groups respectively. These hydroxyl groups located on the inner surface of the mordenite structure can be attributed to stronger Brønsted acidity [37]. Furthermore, a weak band observed around 3655cm−1 corresponds to the extra framework aluminium (AlOH) species. HOH bending vibrational bands were observed at 1636cm−1 and bands due to SiO stretching vibrations were found at 1040cm−1 and 1198cm−1. The pure mordenite revealed a vibrational band at 1480cm−1 assigned to OH vibrations and this band appeared to disappear gradually after metal impregnation suggesting the breaking of OH bond to form OM. Additionally, the bands observed at 918cm−1, 585cm−1, 520cm−1 and 468cm−1 resulted from AlOAl bending vibration, coupling vibration of AlO and SiO, Al-O stretching vibration and SiO bending vibrations respectively [38]. Combined with XRD results, the FTIR spectra below shows that the structure of mordenite did not appreciably appear to be altered after metal impregnation. 3.1.3 TGA-TPD studies The acid site distribution and relative acidic strength of a zeolite catalyst is the characteristic feature used to obtain a correlation with its catalytic activity. The temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of a base (ammonia) molecule from the surface of zeolite catalyst is one efficient technique to measure the acidity of catalysts. Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) of NH3 adsorbed zeolites is a convenient method used for characterization of TPD profiles of zeolites [39]. TGA-TPD studies were performed to identify the desorption of ammonia from metal promoted mordenite catalysts as a function of temperature and the resulting data was used to depict the acid site distribution and strength of acid sites present in various mordenite catalysts. The TGA-TPD profiles of all the samples are presented in Fig. 3 and the amount of acid sites in millimoles per gram of catalyst obtained from the peak minimum of TGA desorption curves are listed in Table 1 . As can be seen from Fig. 3, the TGA-TPD curves showed a gradual weight loss in two different regions. The first weight loss region at lower temperatures (I) corresponds to the presence of weak acid sites due to the desorption of weakly bound ammonia molecules and the second weight loss region found at higher temperatures (II) is attributed to the desorption of strongly bound ammonia molecules [40]. The total acidity values corresponding to pure mordenite (HM) and various metal-promoted mordenite (Fe-Mor, Co-Mor, Ni-Mor, Cu-Mor, Zn-Mor) catalysts are presented in Table 1, calculated by using the following equation: Acidity = % Weight loss 100 1 MW of NH 3 100 mg 1 g The results from Fig. 3 and Table 1 illustrates that the total acidity of pure mordenite is comparatively higher than the metal-promoted mordenite catalysts which is probably due to the blockage of acid sites by metal oxides impregnation on the mordenite surface. This demonstrates that the introduction of transition metal ions substantially modified the inherent acidity of the catalysts. However, among various metal promoted mordenite catalysts, Cu-Mor catalyst exhibited higher affinity towards NH3 and showed higher total acidity. This indicates that Cu-Mor catalyst possess large number of acidic sites compared to other metal-promoted catalysts and can demonstrate a good correlation between the acidity and catalytic activity. 3.1.4 XPS measurements TGA results clearly demonstrated that addition of transition metal ions significantly altered the total acidic sites, therefore it is essential to investigate on how the metal oxides can modify the acidic sites. In metal ions-promoted mordenite catalysts, the transition metal ions either interact with the Brønsted or Lewis acidic sites. Therefore XPS analysis of these catalysts was carried out to understand the nature of interaction (Fig. 4 ). Pure Mordenite has shown three chemically distinct O 1s components of having the peak binding energies of 532.6eV, 533.2eV and 531.6eV respectively [41]. These three O 1s components were assigned to the surface oxides, hydroxides and bulk oxide respectively. In all cases, the O 1s spectral profile showed significant broadening as compared to that of pure mordenite. However, in the case of Cu-Mor catalyst, it was observed that the O 1s component corresponding to the surface oxide species has been shifted to lower binding energies. It is known that the surface oxides and hydroxides significantly contribute to the total acidity of the catalysts, and the O 1s spectra provide a clear indication of the modification of mordenite by transition metal ions. Another major change observed was related to Al 2p core levels after Mor was modified with transition metal ions. Pure mordenite exhibited Al 2p binding energy at 74.3eV, however it was shifted to 74.8eV in the case of Cu-Mor catalyst. All the other metal-modified mordenite catalysts showed significantly broader Al 2p spectra without much change in Al 2p binding energies. Cu 2p core level binding energy in Cu-Mor catalyst was observed at 932.8eV without any satellite features, suggesting the formation of Cu2O species formation on the surface of mordenite [42]. Interestingly, both O 1s and Al 2p core level spectra were broadened in all the metal modified mordenite catalysts whereas the Cu-Mor catalyst showed a shift in binding energy. This is a clear indication of a metal interaction with the acidic sites of mordenite particularly with the Lewis acidic site of Al3+. The XPS analysis clearly revealed that Cu-Mor catalyst demonstrated a strong interaction with mordenite support and the results are in corroboration with TGA-TPD studies. 3.1.5 SEM/EDX studies Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) analysis was used to study the morphological changes of Mor before and after Cu ions modification. The pure mordenite sample (Fig. 5a) exhibited needle-like crystalline morphology, typical characteristic of mordenite zeolites [43]. As seen in Fig. 5b, the Cu-Mor catalyst occur in clusters of closely spaced crystals in the form of fibrous aggregates, and the filaments commonly intertwine into packed mesh like structures. EDX studies were performed to determine the elemental compositions of the Cu-Mor catalyst. The images and spectra generated as a result of elements in the catalyst are presented in Fig. 6 . EDX analysis showed the presence of major elements such as Si, Al, O, and C in the catalyst [44]. In addition, copper is also identified in the Cu-Mor sample which clearly revealed the distribution of copper on the surface of mordenite. 3.2 Catalytic activity results 3.2.1 Screening of catalysts Initially, the screening of different transition metal ions promoted mordenite solid acid catalysts (Fe-Mor, Co-Mor, Ni-Mor, Cu-Mor and Zn-Mor) was performed in order to investigate their efficiency towards glycerol acetalization with acetone to produce solketal. The reactions were carried out using microwave irradiation as a heating method under the same reaction conditions as follows: 40mg catalyst, glycerol/acetone ratio is 1:3, reaction temperature 100°C and a reaction time of 15min. The influence of different catalysts on the conversion of glycerol to solketal was comparatively analyzed and correlated with catalytic properties. Castanheiro et al. [45] investigated glycerol acetalization over different zeolites (USY, BEA and ZSM-5) and found that the catalytic activity was mostly influenced by the pore structure and acidity of catalysts. All zeolites tested presented high selectivity to five-membered ring solketal at about 77–82% (Scheme 3 ). Fig. 7 shows the results of glycerol conversion and selectivity to solketal in acetalization reaction attained by all catalysts. 1,3-dioxalane (5-membered, solketal) was obtained as a major product with high selectivity than the 1,3-dioxane (6-membered) over pure mordenite as well as metal promoted mordenite catalysts. This is because, the five membered ring 1,3-dioaxalne product is kinetically more favourable than the six membered ring 1,3-dioaxane product. It is to be noted that the six membered product although thermodynamically more stable, it is kinetically less favourable as one of the methyl groups occupy axial position. Hence glycerol acetalization with acetone favours the formation of five-membered ring transition state which leads to the formation of solketal. Similar findings were reported in the previous studies [13,45,46]. The glycerol acetalization over pure mordenite resulted in 66% glycerol conversion with 64% and 36% selectivity to 5-M and 6-M products respectively. Interestingly, over metal ions promoted mordenite catalysts, the glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity increased significantly with a decline in the selectivity of 1,3-dioxane (6-membered). All the metal promoted mordenite (Fe-Mor, Co-Mor, Ni-Mor, Cu-Mor and Zn-Mor) catalysts exhibited appreciable activities of glycerol conversion (86–95%) and solketal selectivity (81–98%). A blank reaction without using any catalyst was also performed which showed about 8% glycerol conversion and no selectivity towards solketal. This indicates that catalyst mediated glycerol acetalization reaction provides high efficiency glycerol conversion and product selectivity. The highest glycerol conversion of 95% was obtained over Cu-Mor catalyst with a solketal selectivity of 98%. This result can be explained based on the greater acidity of the Cu-Mor catalyst and better interaction of Cu with the mordenite support which influenced the progression of the reaction. 3.2.2 Reaction optimization Several reaction parameters were surveyed to achieve the optimized conditions in microwave assisted synthesis of solketal from glycerol acetalization over the best performed Cu-Mor catalyst. The reaction temperature, glycerol/acetone molar ratio, microwave power and reaction time were varied to improve the glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity. 3.2.2.1 Reaction temperature Different experiments were carried out by varying the reaction temperature in the microwave from 40°C to 120°C, in order to evaluate its effect on the acetalization of glycerol with acetone over Cu-Mor catalyst. The results of effect of reaction temperature on glycerol conversion and on the selectivity to solketal are shown in Fig. 8 . As anticipated, the glycerol conversion increased with the temperature and reached maximum (95%) at 100°C (Fig. 8). It was observed that when the acetalization of glycerol with acetone was carried out at 40°C the selectivity to solketal was found to be 88% and increased to 98% at 100°C. When the reaction temperature is further increased to 120°C, there was a slight decrease in the solketal selectivity although the glycerol conversion remained constant. Therefore 100°C was chosen as the optimum reaction temperature in microwave assisted synthesis of glycerol acetalization. 3.2.2.2 Molar ratio of glycerol to acetone The ratio or amount of the reactants in a chemical reaction plays a crucial role in controlling the product formation and hence it is imperative to optimize the reaction by using the precise molar ratio of reactants to achieve better conversion and selectivity of products. In order to investigate the optimum glycerol:acetone molar ratio required for glycerol acetalization, reactions were carried out by using various proportions of glycerol:acetone such as 1:1, 1:2, 1:3 and 1:4 at 100°C. Table 2 presents results of the effect of molar ratio of glycerol to acetone on glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity. The results clearly show that glycerol conversion and selectivity to solketal gradually raised up by increasing the glycerol:acetone molar ratio from 1:1 to 1:3. However, when the molar ratio of glycerol to acetone increases from 1:3 to 1:4, there was no further increase in solketal selectivity but a slight fall in the glycerol conversion was noticed. This can be ascribed to the saturation of acetone over the active sites available for glycerol to react. Similar outcomes were observed in the literature [22,47]. 3.2.2.3 Microwave power The glycerol acetalization was systematically studied using microwave power ranging from 100 to 600W at 100°C and with 1:3 glycerol/acetone molar ratio. As shown in Fig. 9 , a noticeable increase in the glycerol conversion was observed with increase in the microwave power from 100 to 600W. The selectivity to solketal was found to be considerably high in all experiments and attained 98% at 500W microwave power. This is ascribed to the highly accelerated reaction by the microwave irradiation. 3.2.2.4 Effect of catalyst amount The effect of catalyst amount on glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity during acetalization of glycerol was studied by varying the amount of catalyst from 20mg to 60mg at 100°C, 500W and 1:3 glycerol/acetone molar ratio. As presented in Fig. 10 , the glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity increased from 90% to 95% and 92% to 98% respectively, with increase in the catalyst amount from 20mg to 40mg, which is due to the availability of greater number of active sites in the catalyst. It is observed that there is no further variation in the conversion and selectivity beyond that weight of catalyst amount and hence 40mg of catalyst is considered to be the optimum amount for the reaction. 3.2.2.5 Reaction time The reaction was monitored at different reaction times from 5min to 20min and Fig. 11 shows the results of effect of reaction time over Cu-Mor catalyst at 100°C and 500W microwave power with a molar ratio of glycerol to acetone 1:3. After 5min of reaction time, the reaction resulted in 80% conversion of glycerol with 70% selectivity to solketal. Gradually, with increase in reaction time to 15min, the maximum glycerol conversion (95%) and solketal selectivity (98%) was achieved. Further increase in the reaction time to 20min did not result in significant increase in the activity, hence 15min was considered to be the optimum reaction time in the present study. 3.2.3 Glycerol acetalization at room temperature The glycerol acetalization with acetone was carried out at room temperature using 1:3 glycerol/acetone ratio and 50mg catalyst. The reaction proceeded very slowly and reached 75% glycerol conversion and 80% solketal selectivity after 2h reaction time. This is possibly due to the poor interaction of catalyst active sites with the reactant molecules in the reaction to accelerate the reaction. The results of glycerol acetalization at room temperature are presented in Fig. 12 . In contrast, microwave irradiation enhanced the activity to a greater extent and resulted in high glycerol conversion (95%) and solketal selectivity (98%) within 15min of reaction. The rapid internal heating of reactants by microwave energy was highly efficient to promote the active interactions between the reactant molecules and the active sites on the catalyst surface. Microwave irradiation process was highly efficient and accelerated the reaction rate by remarkably decreasing the reaction time from hours to minutes [48]. Therefore microwave-assisted synthesis of solketal from glycerol acetalization over Cu-Mor catalyst was found to be a promising route over conventional methods. 3.2.4 Proposed reaction mechanism Previous literature shows that the majority of glycerol acetalization reactions with different carbonyl compounds have been promoted by solid acid catalysts [21,22,49]. Accordingly, the present study demonstrates the glycerol acetalization reaction over acidic zeolite catalysts. The possible reaction pathway for solketal formation through acetalization of glycerol with acetone over metal promoted mordenite catalysts is shown in Scheme 4 . The acidic sites of metal promoted mordenite catalysts aided in the effective acetalization of glycerol with acetone. Initially, the oxygen atom of the carbonyl group of acetone strongly coordinates with the catalyst generating a positively charged carbonyl carbon which is then attacked by a lone pair on oxygen atoms of glycerol and results in the formation of tertiary alcohol intermediate. In the next step, the proton released from acidic sites of the catalyst facilitates the protonation of the intermediate. Finally, the other nucleophilic hydroxyl group of glycerol attacks the tertiary carbon of the intermediate with simultaneous elimination of water molecule. This affords 5-membered and 6-membered isomeric cyclic products namely (2, 2-dimethyl-[1,3] dioxane-4-yl)-methanol (also known as Solketal) and 2, 2-dimethyl-[1,3] dioxane-5-ol (acetal) respectively. When secondary hydroxyl group is involved, a 5 membered solketal is formed and a 6 membered acetal product is obtained when primary hydroxyl group of glycerol is involved in the attack. The 5-membered cyclic product (solketal) was found to be the major product in the present study which is in accordance with earlier reports. 3.2.5 Recyclability studies In order to investigate the catalyst stability, the recyclability studies of glycerol acetalization were performed over Cu-Mor catalyst. The spent catalyst was recovered by simple centrifugation and washed with water several times to remove the impurities adsorbed on the catalyst surface. It is then oven dried at 100°C for 2–3h and the catalyst was reused directly for glycerol acetalization reaction in microwave under the same optimized reaction conditions used for the fresh catalyst [50]. The reused catalyst samples were also subjected to XRD, FT-IR, and TGA-TPD analyses. XRD and FTIR results did not show any significant changes in features of used catalyst compared to fresh catalyst. However, there was a slight decline in the acidity of spent sample after the fourth reaction cycle indicating that there could be slight deactivation of Cu-Mor catalyst. Fig. 12 shows the catalytic activity results of glycerol conversion and solketal selectivity for five reaction cycles. The results show that the catalyst remained stable with no significant change in the glycerol conversion and selectivity of solketal up to four reaction cycles whereas a slight decline in activity was observed after fourth reaction cycle of glycerol acetalization. The observed drop in the activity could be attributed to the partial deactivation of catalyst due to the blockage of acidic sites (Fig. 13 ). 4 Conclusions In summary, a sustainable method of solketal synthesis from acetalization of glycerol using microwave irradiation is presented. Mordenite and transition metal-promoted mordenite catalysts were found to be highly efficient solid acid catalysts for glycerol acetalization. Cu-Mor catalyst exhibited excellent activity among all the tested catalysts and achieved 98% selectivity to solketal at 95% glycerol conversion under the optimized reaction conditions of 1:3 glycerol/acetone molar ratio, 100°C, 500W microwave power and 15min reaction time. Compared to the room temperature synthesis of solketal from glycerol acetalization, microwave-assisted solketal synthesis showed great efficacy due to the high energy microwave process. The catalytic activity is well correlated with acidity of the catalyst and Cu-Mor catalyst was found to be efficiently reusable for consecutive catalytic reaction cycles. coredata.dc:description: The present study demonstrates a clean and green approach for the production of bio-fuel additives from renewable glycerol acetalization using microwave irradiation as heating method. Various transition metal ion (M=Fe-, Co-, Ni-, Cu- & Zn-) promoted mordenite solid acid catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method and examined for the acetalization of glycerol with acetone. Investigation of the structural and chemical properties of the catalysts was achieved using XRD, FT-IR, TGA-TPD, SEM/EDX and XPS techniques. Comparative studies using conventional heating were performed in order to study the efficiency of microwave-assisted acetalization reactions. The effect of various operating parameters on the catalytic activity studies was examined. Amongst the metal-promoted mordenite catalysts tested, Cu-Mor had the best performance due to the presence of a large amount of acidic sites and the synergetic effects of metal particles interacting with mordenite. Microwave-assisted acetalization of glycerol into Solketal was found to be an energy efficient route for glycerol valorization achieving 98% selectivity to solketal at 95% glycerol conversion during a reaction time of 15min over Cu-Mor catalyst and acetone/glycerol at a molar ratio of 3:1. Reuse of spent catalyst showed good repeatability for up to four reaction cycles with a marginal decrease in conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Solvent-free microwave-assisted synthesis of solketal from glycerol using transition metal ions promoted mordenite solid acid catalysts
